Introduction

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is a new acute trust created on 1st April 2020 following the merger of the three acute trusts; Basildon University Hospitals NHS Foundation trust, Mid Essex Hospital NHS trust and Southend University Hospital NHS.

The Trust provides a range of clinical services and care for a population of over 1.2 million people in central and south Essex across the three main sites; Basildon, Broomfield and Southend Hospital. The trust also runs services from community hospitals including Braintree Community Hospital, Brentwood Community Hospital, Orsett Hospital and St Peter's Hospital.

All Trust staff have a responsibility for infection prevention and control. Specialist advice and support will be provided via the Infection Prevention and Control Team (IPCT) and where relevant the Consultant Microbiologist /Virologist and Infection Control Doctor.

The purpose of the Infection Prevention and Control Safety is to ensure that the Trust provides an environment and systems of care which minimises the risk of infection to patients, staff and visitors.
The key objectives of this strategy are to:
Set out the principles and framework for the prevention and control of infection within the Trust
Ensure that all staff understand their roles and responsibilities in connection with the prevention and control of infection within the Trust
Ensure compliance with national policy and guidance related to infection prevention and control
Framework
The Trust shall implement policies and procedures for the prevention and control of infections. Compliance with all Trust policies is mandatory

This strategy and all associated procedural documents, audit tools and information will be continually reviewed and updated to reflect evolving clinical practice, up to date legislation and guidance relevant to infection control
Prevention
The Infection Prevention and Control Team will:
Provide surveillance and rapid feedback on infection rates and alert organisms to clinical areas
Ensure the provision of timely information, advice and support to all Trust employees, patients and visitors on matters relating to Infection Prevention and Control

Support local investigations and management of incidents relating to infectious diseases and alert organisms to enable clinical teams to prevent further incidence through learning and service improvement
Provide advice regarding infection prevention and control aspects of new builds/refurbishments
Control

When  an  incident  occurs,  or  when  patients  are  potentially,  or  confirmed  to  be, infected/colonised with an infectious agent or diagnosed with an infectious disease, the patients care will be managed in accordance with the Trusts relevant infection prevention and control procedures.

Staff with infections or who are at risk of infection through exposure or inoculation injury  will  be  managed  in  accordance  with  Occupational  Health  and  safety procedures related to the prevention of transmission of infection
Scope
Implementing the control of infection prevention and control measures applies to all Trust employees both permanent and temporary and visitors

data.text: Roles & Responsibilities within the Trust
MSE Infection Prevention and Control Committee
Advising and supporting the IPCT team;
Review of this Strategy at least every two years, but more frequently if there are changes to Infection Prevention and Control Legislation/ guidance/IPC Structure
Drawing to the attention of the Chief Executive, either through the DIPC or, if necessary, directly, any serious problems or hazards relating to infection prevention and control;
Considering reports on infections and infection prevention and control problems;

Discussing and endorsing a plan for the management of outbreaks in the Trust and monitoring its implementation; Collaborating with the IPCTs to develop the annual infection prevention and control programme, monitor its progress, assist in its effective implementation and review the annual report;
Providing advice regarding the most effective use of resources available for implementation of the programme and for contingency requirements;
Advising on and approving all infection prevention and control policies;
Promoting and facilitating the education of all grades of staff in infection prevention and control procedures.

Site Infection Prevention and Control Committees are responsible for the review of this Strategy at least every two years, but more frequently if there are changes to Infection Prevention and Control Legislation/ guidance/IPC Structure .The final version is then presented at the MSE IPCC for agreement
Managing Director is responsible for ensuring that the Trust is in a position to provide an overall assurance that the organisation has in place the necessary controls to manage IPC.
Chief Medical Officer is the Director of Infection Prevention and Control (DIPC) and reports directly to the Trust Board.
Has the Executive authority and responsibility for ensuring the implementation strategies to prevent avoidable HCAI
Has overall responsibility for the provision for IPC on behalf of the Board
of Directors
To continuously improve the Trust's performance in relation to HCAI
Is the lead on infection prevention and control for the organisation and ensures the organisation's clinical governance and patient safety teams and structures are in line with policy
Supports the Director of Nursing for Harm free care in identifying and planning actions to mitigate infection control risk within the Trust
Director of Nursing for Harm Free care is responsible for:
Ensuring sufficient resources are in place to implement this strategy
Liaison between DIPC / Trust Board and the IPCT
Production of appropriate reports to the Board
Management of the nursing structures for IPC through the Associate Director of Harm Free Care
The Infection Prevention and Control BAF, risk register and action log for the trust.
Escalation to the Chief Medical Officer of trust IPC risks and concerns/ performance
Oversee local management of Infection Prevention and Control policies and their implementation
Ensure appropriate information is available for patients, visitors and the public
Assess the impact of all existing and new policies and plans on infection and make recommendations for change
Oversee the production of the annual report on behalf of the Chief Medical Director
Associate Director Harm Free Care works in partnership and Deputises for the Director Harm Free Care
Line manages and supports of the Head Nurse Infection Prevention and Control
Has the responsibility to ensure there are adequate resources available to manage Infection Prevention and Control Service for the Trust
Reviews and updates the Infection Prevention and Control BAF, risk register and action log
Production of appropriate reports to the Board
Site Based Director of Infection Prevention and Control (DIPC) responsible for:
Leading the site based infection prevention and control groups
Reviewing the site based performance and implementing strategies to reduce HCAI in their care groups.
Approve the Infection Prevention and Control annual plan
Oversee local management of Infection Prevention and Control policies and their implementation
Report directly to the site based Managing Director and the Chief Medical Officer
Have the authority to challenge inappropriate clinical hygiene practice as well as antibiotic prescribing decisions
Assess the impact of all existing and new policies and plans on infection and make recommendations for change
Escalate risks to the Director of Nursing for Harm free care for consideration to be included in the BAF, risk register or risk log

The Head Nurse for Infection Control MSE is accountable to the Director for Harm Free Care for achieving the Trust's goal in relation to Infection Prevention and Control. The Head Nurse provides clinical and professional leadership to the members of the IPCT. As a senior nurse within the organisation the Head Nurse for

IPC provides visible clinical leadership, working collaboratively with the Chief Nurse/DIPC, ICD, Consultant Microbiologist and local Infection Control leads including the local health authority. The Head Nurse for Infection Control will support the DIPC with the production of the Infection Prevention and Control Annual Report.
Lead Nurses for Infection Prevention and Control

The Lead nurses for Infection Prevention and Control line manage the Infection Prevention and control team at the relevant sites. The lead nurses work in partnership with the Head Nurse IPC, Microbiologist, Virologist and the ICD.

The lead nurses also have specific role in nursing leadership, service improvement and oversee the implementation of the Trust Infection Prevention and Control annual work plan. The lead nurses provide the clinical nursing expertise to the team to ensure that the strategy and associated polices are appropriate and applicable.
The lead nurses for IPC support the development of monthly, quarterly and annual reports as required by the Board of Directors.
Infection Prevention and Control Teams (IPCT) are responsible for:
Working with all Trust staff in order to ensure best Infection Prevention and Control practice throughout the Trust
To be available to provide advice and guidance to any member of staff regarding Infection Prevention and Control issues
Provide reports relating to alert organisms, outbreaks and issues related to infection prevention and control
Link in with external partners , such as the CCG and PHE to ensure a system wide approach and maintain contractual requirements
Formulation of up to date evidence based hand hygiene guidelines
Advising the trust on the most appropriate alcohol hand rub/liquid soap to use in clinical practice
Responsible for uploading the Mandatory Surveillance data onto the HPA website
Providing IPC and hand hygiene education/training for all staff
Supporting the Occupational Health Department with appropriate advice
To provide a clinical advisory service for the prevention, surveillance, investigation and control of infection for patients and health care staff
To work closely together on a day to day basis with the Head of Infection Control leading the overall clinical service
Consider Infection Prevention and Control issues for new equipment, and consult with relevant groups regarding any relevant issues, including capital project programmes
Supporting Ward Managers with the RCA process, and where required the lessons learned are disseminated
The Care Group Leads will be responsible for ensuring that the IPC Strategy is implemented effectively across all services which will include:
The dissemination of the Strategy and allocation of responsibilities for implementation to Associate Directors of Nursing and staff.
Ensuring that IPC is incorporated into all service planning, performance management, project management, and other related processes.
Establishing key IPC risk indicators which are monitored, reviewed, and reported as part of the governance, performance and accountability reporting
Ensuring that IPC is included as a core item on all management team briefings/meetings.
Ensuring that where necessary, HCAI prevention and control risks are reported on the care group Risk Register/ risk log

Reporting on performance against agreed IPC objectives, ensuring that any investigations or enquiries into HCAIs or other IPC issues (including root cause analyses) are completed promptly, thoroughly and to agreed
timescales.

Consultant Microbiologists/Virologist /ICD are responsible for working with the DIPC and Head Nurse for Infection Control supporting them by providing guidance and advice on matters relating to clinically relevant microbiological issues e.g. clinical Infection Prevention and Control activity, anti-biotic prescribing, laboratory issues, surveillance and epidemiology. They also liaise with the DIPC / The Head Nurse for Infection Control on key operational issues as necessary. They will attend the IPCC meetings. The ICD/Consultant Microbiologist will advise and support the Laboratory Manager/Pathology Manager /Trust Medical Director in regards to Infection Prevention and Control issues.

Antibiotic Pharmacist is accountable to the Board for achieving the Trust's goal in relation to infection prevention and control. The Antibiotic Pharmacist is responsible for overseeing anti-biotic prescribing practices and undertaking antibiotic audits and training. This includes the coordination, review, writing and updating of antibiotic policies Trust-wide in liaison with the Infection Control Doctor/Consultant Microbiologist.

Antibiotic Pharmacist provides reports to the Infection prevention and control groups. Monitor and advise care groups on the optimal and cost effective prescribing of antimicrobial agents and facilitate the development, implementation and audit of policies, guidelines and protocols related to antimicrobial prescribing, with reference to local variations in antimicrobial susceptibility.
Matrons will ensure, as far as reasonably practicable that:
Leading and driving a culture of cleanliness in clinical areas
Monitor standards of cleanliness in clinical areas
Ensuring implementation of the Trust HCAI prevention and control policies and procedures
Ensuring regular evaluation of the policy and procedures as practised in their area of responsibility
Participate in root cause analysis where required to promote learning and practice improvement
There are adequate resources available to meet Infection Prevention and Control requirements in the clinical areas
Ensuring that audits are completed and, where necessary, the appropriate actions are instigated to ensure 100% compliance with expected
standards

Ensuring that all their staff receive appropriate training and have the necessary knowledge to practice safe infection control procedures, including ensuring staff are able to attend mandatory hand hygiene training
Ensuring Hand Hygiene audits are performed in line with the requirements set by the IPCC. Addressing deficits in practice to achieve compliance
Ensuring sufficient supplies of necessary cleaning / decontamination resources are available
Attendance at the Infection control group for their care group presenting their reports of practice, actions taken, escalation of concerns and shared learning
Clinical Site Managers to ensure there is no inappropriate movement of patients unless there is an urgent clinical need.

Senior Director of Estates and Facilities will ensure that the Trust provides and maintains a clean and appropriate environment in managed premises that facilitate the prevention and control of infections and that National Standards of Cleanliness are met.

Decontamination Sterile Service Manager supports the IPCTs and clinical teams providing expert advice and guidance on all decontamination issues concerning medical device decontamination and decontamination processes across the Trust ensuring that national guidance and recommendations for decontamination are implemented

Facilities Management and Estates Staff work closely with IPCT, Head of Infection Control MSE, Ward Managers, Matrons and Domestic Services staff to ensure a safe environment and ensuring that contractors adhere to IPC Policies and procedures. This includes the following:
Cleanliness audits
Escalation and corrective action where the required standard is not met
Water safety
Waste management

Laboratory Services are responsible for ensuring the Trust had secure adequate access  to  laboratory  support  as  appropriate.  The  Trust  must be  complaint  with Criterion 8 of the Health and Social Care Act with microbiology laboratory policy for investigation and surveillance of antimicrobial resistance and healthcare associated infections. There must be standard operating procedures for the examination of specimens and timely reporting of results.
Infection Prevention and Control Link Nurses are facilitators of good practice in IPC within their area of work. The IPC Link Nurses:
Attend IPC link meetings and feedback the information gained to colleagues
Facilitate implementation of IPC policies and processes
Act as a resource to staff in their area of work
Participate in standard setting and audit and champion best practice
All employees
Whilst at work, employees have a duty to:

Take reasonable care of their own health and safety at work and of other persons who may be affected by their acts or omissions – this includes adherence to infection control recommendations of preventative measures to minimise transmission to others
Report infection control hazards in the workplace
Participate in training which is offered to them
Undertake mandatory training
Adhering to all policies and challenging others who may not be compliant
Patients, Relatives, Carers and Visitors
Patients must be advised and encouraged to decontaminate their hands after using the toilet, before consumption of food or drink
Patient must be advised on their role in preventing transmission of infections
Relatives , carers and visitors are encouraged to decontaminate their hands when entering and leaving a ward or department
Relatives, carers and visitors MUST be advised of the need to decontaminate their hands before and after direct contact with patients
Relatives , carers and visitors must be advised on their role in preventing transmission of infections
Key forums for the Management and Monitoring of Infection
Prevention and Control Activities
The Quality Governance Committee:

The purpose of the Quality Governance Committee is to assure the Trust Board that appropriate processes are in place to give confidence that all Quality, patient safety performance and associated risks are monitored effectively and that appropriate actions are taken to address any deviation from accepted standards and to manage identified risks.
The Patient Safety & Quality Group:

The Patient Safety and Quality Group is accountable to the Quality Governance Committee. It has been established to oversee and coordinate all aspects of quality improvement (patient experience/patient safety & clinical effectiveness), assurance and clinical governance activity and delivery by the care groups. This includes all infection prevention and control activity within its portfolio.
Risk and Compliance Group:

The risk and compliance group is accountable to the Quality Governance Committee. It has been established to oversee and coordinate all aspects of risk and compliance with National, Regulatory and local compliance. This includes the monitoring of risks, emerging risks and risk logs for the trust and care groups for infection control where escalation is required to the BAF, Corporate risk register/ corporate risk log.
The MSE Infection Prevention and Control Steering Group will:
Develop new strategies to address Infection Prevention and Control issues within the acute setting and the wider health community.
Review Infection Control audit data and monitor actions.
Develop and review Policies and make minor alterations as appropriate and present to Infection Prevention and Control Committee.
Facilitate the implementation of ratified policies.
Monitor progress on actions identified at the RCA Group Meetings
Agree, amend and monitor the progress of Healthcare Associated Infection Action Plans.
Raise issues of concerns to the Executive Management Team via the Director of Infection Prevention and Control

The Medicines Assurance Group (MAG) provides strategic direction and a framework to oversee implementation of the Trust's Medicines Optimisation strategy. It supports delivery of high quality multidisciplinary leadership and governance for clinical and cost-effective use of medicines across the Trust.
To provide advice on the safe and effective use of medicines throughout the Trust.
To acknowledge, approve, and take action from reports and escalated items from MAG sub-groups:
Antimicrobial stewardship Group;
Immunoglobulins (Ig) Virtual Panel;
Supply of Medicines sub-group;
Formulary sub-group;
To ensure that appropriate lessons from medication incidents and audit are learnt, shared and corrective action implemented, guided by the Medication
Safety Officer (MSO)
The Matrons Forum:

The Matrons Forum provides an interactive forum which receives, reviews and implements national and local policy relating to patient care, including infection control practice. This forum enables the process of communication, debate, sharing of knowledge and opportunity.
IPC Link Practitioner Group

The IPC Link Practitioner programme continues to be a very successful cascade system and is served by link practitioners from a variety of clinical services/teams. The membership is made up a variety of grades and professions reflecting the diversity of services across the organisation. The group is designed to promote communication, education and shared practice on all activities relating to infection prevention and control. Staff feedback is actively encouraged.
Education and Training
The Infection Prevention and Control Service recommends that this strategy must be included as part of an individual's induction:
Infection Prevention and Control practice should be included in staff meetings and during mandatory training
Bi-annual mandatory Hand Hygiene / Infection Prevention and Control update training sessions are provided
Additional / optional Infection Control workshops/induction talks are delivered when required, as well as targeted ward / departmental based training sessions
Training sessions will be delivered according to national guidance. A training register will be maintained of all teaching sessions provided.
Surveillance and audit

Good, accurate and meaningful information and data to plan service delivery, evaluate progress and demonstrates improvements is an essential requirement of the infection control agenda. Infection control surveillance data plays a central role in providing the information needed to underpin strategic objectives as well as informing priorities and focus for day to day operations. Infection reduction programmes can only be demonstrated as being effective if accurate rates of infection are known. Incorporation of an effective surveillance programme with regular feedback of results to clinical staff is recognised as crucial to the development of action plans to facilitate reductions in the incidence of HCAIs. Clinical Divisions, in partnership with the infection Control Teams will decide upon appropriate surveillance programmes. The Divisions will be responsible for the implementation of surveillance with close collaboration and support from the Infection Control Team. Adequate staffing and good management arrangements will be needed to ensure success and the Trust will review the resources available to support the surveillance programme. The Infection Control Teams will, alongside the infection control site leads, review the results of the surveillance programmes on a monthly regular basis and produce action plans aimed at reducing the level of HCAI.

Clinical audit provides an important tool to monitor the implementation of policies and operational performance. It can also provide insight into problems highlighted by surveillance. Infection control audit will need to be strengthened and included as part of the Trust's programme of clinical audit. The Infection Control Team will work closely with Divisions to advise and agree on the topics and priorities for audit.
Notifiable Diseases
The Infection Prevention and Control Department will report all other notifiable incidents. I.e. outbreaks of diarrhoea and vomiting, COVID-19, MRSA, CDI etc.
Risk Assessment

Healthcare associated infections continue to cause substantial patient morbidity and cost to the health service. National surveys suggest that 9% of inpatients have a hospital-associated infection at any time costing as much as £1 billion a year with around 15% being preventable through better application of good practice (National Audit Office 2009).

Establishing the infection status of a patient prior to hospital attendance or, if this is impractical,  confirming patient's infection status  upon a patient's admission is a major part of risk assessment.
Service Development and Infection Prevention and Control

The Head Nurse for Infection Control and Infection Prevention and Control Teams must be involved from the early planning stage to completion and evaluation of forthcoming developments, refurbishments and all stages of construction, including the final commissioning of new or upgrades of facilities.
Board Assurance
The Executive Team will receive exception reporting within the care group accountability meetings.
The Board will receive performance reports on HCAI
The Infection Prevention and Control Board Assurance Frame Work (BAF)

Quarterly and Annual Reports which include Clostridium difficile data, MRSA bacteraemia cases, Gram Negative blood steam infection rates (BSI), outbreaks of infection , and Serious Incidents related to HCAI

Additionally, the Infection Prevention and Control annual report and Quarterly progress reports on other issues (e.g. compliance with the Health Act) will be presented formally to the Risk and Compliance Committee by the DIPC. Evidence of compliance with the Health and Social Care Act Regulations will be collected concurrently throughout the year, and will be provided as additional evidence to assure the Trust board of compliance with this and the Health Act. This will then be reported through the Infection Prevention and Control Annual Report.
Bespoke papers where required
Antimicrobial Management

The  South  East  Essex  Medicines  Management  Committee (SEEMMC)  is  the forum for monitoring this process. This ensures input from the Pharmacy Leads, Microbiologist, Virologist, Primary Care Trust and other interested personnel, the Microbiologist/Infection  Control  Doctor  work  with  other  interested  parties  to standardise antibiotic reporting and use.
Audit / monitoring compliance

An audit programme for Infection Prevention and Control Policies is developed and reviewed on an annual basis; this will be delivered, evaluated and actioned in conjunction with other relevant, appropriate staff / departments. The outcome of compliance  audits  is  reported  through  the  Infection  Prevention  and  Control Committee and Heads of Nursing meetings and is also included in the IPC annual reports
Training Requirements
All  Trust  staff  must  undertake  Mandatory  Infection  Prevention  and  Control updates.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Infection Prevention and Control Committees, which are the specialist groups with the authority to approve local policy. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Director of Harm Free Care of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
